sen.j: 山王信仰（さんのうしんこう）とは、比叡山麓の日吉大社（滋賀県大津市）より生じた神道の信仰である。
sen.e: Sanno Shinko is a belief of shinto originated from Hiyoshi Taisha shrine at the foot of Mt. Hiei (Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture).
Sanno Shinko is a belief of Shinto originated from Hiyoshi Taisha shrine at the foot of Mt. Hiei (Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture).
Sanno Shinko is a belief of Shinto originated from Hiyoshi Taisha shrine at the foot of Mt. Hiei (Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture).

sen.j: 日吉神社・日枝神社（ひよしじんじゃ、ひえじんじゃ）あるいは山王神社などという社名の神社は山王信仰に基づいて日吉大社より勧請を受けた神社で、大山咋神と大物主（または大国主）を祭神とし、日本全国に約3,800社ある。
sen.e: Shrines named like Hiyoshijinja Shrine, Hieijinja Shrine, and Sannojinja Shrine are branched from Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine based on the belief in the mountain deity, which is called Sanno Shinko belief, for 3,800 shrines throughout Japan enshrining Ooyamakuinokami and Oomononushinokami (or Okuninushinokami).

Shrines named like Hiyoshijinja Shrine, Hiejinja Shrine, and Sannojinja Shrine are branched from Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine based on the belief in the mountain deity, which is called Sanno Shinko belief, and there are approximately 3,800 brunch shrines throughout Japan enshrining Ooyamakuinokami and Oomononushinokami (or Okuninushinokami).
sen.cmt: HieijinjaをHiejinjaに、後半の文章を修正しました。
sen.e: Shrines named like Hiyoshijinja Shrine, Hiejinja Shrine, and Sannojinja Shrine are branched from Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine based on the belief in the mountain deity, which is called Sanno Shinko belief, and there are approximately 3,800 brunch shrines throughout Japan enshrining Ooyamakuinokami and Oomononushinokami (or Okuninushinokami).

sen.j: 神仏習合期には山王（さんのう。山王権現、日吉山王など）と称され、今日でも山王さんの愛称で親しまれている。
sen.e: During the amalgamation of Buddhism with the indigenous religion Shinto, the shrines were named Sanno, Sannno-Gongen, Hiyoshi-Sanno, and the like, and now they are nicknamed Sanno-san.
During the amalgamation of Buddhism with the indigenous religion Shinto, the shrines were named Sanno, Sanno-Gongen, Hiyoshi-Sanno, and the like, and now they are nicknamed Sanno-san.
During the amalgamation of Buddhism with the indigenous religion Shinto, the shrines were named Sanno, Sanno-Gongen, Hiyoshi-Sanno, and the like, and now they are nicknamed Sanno-san.

sen.j: サルを神使とする。
sen.e: Monkey is considered the sacred messenger from the deities.
Monkey is considered the sacred messenger from the deities.
Monkey is considered the sacred messenger from the deities.

sen.j: 山王とは、滋賀県大津市坂本の日吉（ひえ）神社（大社）の別名である。
sen.e: Sanno is another name for Hieijinja Shrine (also known as Hieitaisha Shrine) in Sakamoto, Otsu city, Shiga Prefecture.
Sanno is another name for Hiejinja Shrine (also known as Hietaisha Shrine) in Sakamoto, Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture.
sen.cmt: HieijをHie, cityをCityに修正しました。
sen.e: Sanno is another name for Hiejinja Shrine (also known as Hietaisha Shrine) in Sakamoto, Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture.

sen.j: 日吉神社は、もともと近江国日枝山（ひえのやま：後に比叡山の字が充てられた）の神である「大山咋神」（おおやまくいのかみ）を祀っていたもので、後に近江京遷都の翌年である天智天皇七年（668年）、大津京鎮護のため大和国三輪山（三諸山（みもろやま）とも）の大三輪神（おおみわのかみ）、すなわち大物主神（おおものぬしのかみ）を勧請しともに祀られた。
sen.e: Hiyoshijinja Shrine originally enshrined Ooyamakuinokami, a deity of Mt. Hiei (originally written as 日枝山 and later as 比叡山) in Omi Province; and in 668, the next year of relocation of capital to Omikyo, Oomikawanokami, i.e., Oomononushinokami, of Mt. Miwa (also known as Mt. Mimoro) in Yamato Province was branched to be enshrined with Ooyamakuinokami to protect the new capital Ootsukyo.

Hiyoshijinja Shrine originally enshrined Ooyamakuinokami, a deity of Mt. Hiei (originally written as 日枝山 and later as 比叡山) in Omi Province; and in 668, the next year of relocation of capital to Omikyo, Oomikawanokami, i.e., Oomononushinokami, of Mt. Miwa (also known as Mt. Mimoro) in Yamato Province was transferred to the shrine to be enshrined with Ooyamakuinokami to protect the new capital Otsukyo.
sen.cmt: 勧請の訳はここではbranchではなくtransferが適切だと思われます。
sen.e: Hiyoshijinja Shrine originally enshrined Ooyamakuinokami, a deity of Mt. Hiei (originally written as 日枝山 and later as 比叡山) in Omi Province; and in 668, the next year of relocation of capital to Omikyo, Oomikawanokami, i.e., Oomononushinokami, of Mt. Miwa (also known as Mt. Mimoro) in Yamato Province was transferred to the shrine to be enshrined with Ooyamakuinokami to protect the new capital Otsukyo.

sen.j: 比叡山に天台宗の延暦寺ができてからは、大山咋神・大物主神は地主神として天台宗・延暦寺の守護神とされた。
sen.e: After Enryakuji Temple of the Tendai sect was constructed on Mt. Hiei, Ooyamakuinokami and Oomononushinokami have been venerated as tutelary deities of the temple as they have been protecting deities of the region.

After Enryakuji Temple of the Tendai sect was constructed on Mt. Hiei, Ooyamakuinokami and Oomononushinokami were venerated as tutelary deities of the temple as they were guardian deities of the region.
sen.cmt: 時制および「地主神」の訳語を修正しました。
sen.e: After Enryakuji Temple of the Tendai sect was constructed on Mt. Hiei, Ooyamakuinokami and Oomononushinokami were venerated as tutelary deities of the temple as they were guardian deities of the region.

sen.j: 唐の天台山国清寺が地主神として「山王弼真君」を祀っていることに因み、延暦寺ではこの両神を「山王」と称した。
sen.e: Following suit of Kokuseiji Temple on Mt. Tendaisai in Tang that enshrined '山王弼真君' as its tutelary deity, Enryakuji Temple called the deities '山王' Sanno.
sen.cmt: 「山王弼真君」の読み方が不明です。
sen.e: Following suit of Kokuseiji Temple on Mt. Tendai in Tang that enshrined 'Sanno Genhitsu shinkun' as the guardian deity of the region, Enryakuji Temple called the deities Sanno.
sen.cmt: Mt. Tendaisaiを Mt. Tendai「地主神」の訳語を修正しました。山王元弼真君（さんのうげんひつしんくん）は日吉大社HPに記載がありました。
sen.e: Following suit of Kokuseiji Temple on Mt. Tendai in Tang that enshrined 'Sanno Genhitsu shinkun' as the guardian deity of the region, Enryakuji Temple called the deities Sanno.

sen.j: そして天台宗・延暦寺の守護神としての崇敬が、山王信仰へと発展しやがては「山王神道」とも呼ばれる信仰をも派生させた。
sen.e: The worship of the deities as the tutelary deities of Enryakuji Temple of the Tendai sect developed into the Sanno Shinko belief, from which a belief called 'Sanno shinto' was further derived later.
The worship of the deities as the tutelary deities of Enryakuji Temple of the Tendai sect developed into the Sanno Shinko belief, from which a belief called 'Sanno shinto' was further derived later.
The worship of the deities as the tutelary deities of Enryakuji Temple of the Tendai sect developed into the Sanno Shinko belief, from which a belief called 'Sanno shinto' was further derived later.

sen.j: 山王神道では山王神は釈迦の垂迹であるとされ、「山」の字も「王」の字も、三本の線とそれを貫く一本の線からなっており、これを天台宗の思想である三諦即一思想と結びつけて説いた。
sen.e: In the Sanno shinto, it was considered that the deities of Sanno are manifestation of Shakyamuni, and as each of the Chinese characters '山' and '王' consists of three lines and a line going through the three lines, the Sanno shinto worship was taught in connection with the thoughts of the Tendai sect known as Santai Sokuitsu, meaning three forms of truth is originally one thing.

In the Sanno shinto, it was considered that the deities of Sanno are manifestation of Shakyamuni, and as each of the Chinese characters '山' and '王' consists of three lines and a line going through the three lines, the Sanno shinto worship was taught in connection with the thoughts of the Tendai sect known as Santai Sokuitsu, meaning three forms of truth is originally one thing.

In the Sanno shinto, it was considered that the deities of Sanno are manifestation of Shakyamuni, and as each of the Chinese characters '山' and '王' consists of three lines and a line going through the three lines, the Sanno shinto worship was taught in connection with the thoughts of the Tendai sect known as Santai Sokuitsu, meaning three forms of truth is originally one thing.

sen.j: また天台密教は、鎮護国家、増益延命、息災といった具体的な霊験を加持祈祷によって実現するという体系（使命）を持ち、山王にも「現世利益」を実現する霊威と呪力を高める性格を与えたようである。
sen.e: As the Tendai esoteric Buddhism is systematized to realize specific miracles including the protection of the nation, enrichment and longevity, and good health by the magico-religious rites and prayers as its mission, it gave the Sanno shinto a feature of intensifying mysterious power and magical power to realize 'divine favor in this life'.

As the Tendai esoteric Buddhism is systematized to realize specific miracles including the protection of the nation, enrichment and longevity, and good health by the magico-religious rites and prayers as its mission, it gave the Sanno shinto a feature of intensifying mysterious power and magical power to realize 'divine favor in this life'.

As the Tendai esoteric Buddhism is systematized to realize specific miracles including the protection of the nation, enrichment and longevity, and good health by the magico-religious rites and prayers as its mission, it gave the Sanno shinto a feature of intensifying mysterious power and magical power to realize 'divine favor in this life'.

sen.j: 天台宗が全国に広がる過程で、山王信仰に基づいて日吉社も全国に勧請・創建された。
sen.e: As the Tendai sect was propagated across Japan, Hiyoshijinja Shrine was branched and constructed across Japan based on the Sanno Shinko belief.
As the Tendai sect was propagated across Japan, Hiyoshijinja Shrine was branched and constructed across Japan based on the Sanno Shinko belief.
As the Tendai sect was propagated across Japan, Hiyoshijinja Shrine was branched and constructed across Japan based on the Sanno Shinko belief.

sen.j: 日吉（ひよし）神社・日枝（ひえ）神社、あるいは山王神社などという社名の神社は、日本全国に約3,800社ある。
sen.e: The shrines under the names of Hiyoshijinja Shrine, Hieijinja Shrine, and Sannojinja Shrine count 3,800 in Japan.
There are about 3,800 shrines under the names of Hiyoshijinja Shrine, Hiejinja Shrine, and Sannojinja Shrine in Japan.
sen.cmt: HieiをHieに、 「約3800社ある」の訳を修正しました。
sen.e: There are about 3,800 shrines under the names of Hiyoshijinja Shrine, Hiejinja Shrine, and Sannojinja Shrine in Japan.

sen.j: 神仏習合期には山王（山王権現・日吉山王など）と称され、今日でも山王さんの愛称で親しまれている。
sen.e: During the amalgamation of Buddhism with the indigenous religion Shinto, the shrines were named Sanno, Sannno-Gongen, Hiyoshi-Sanno, and the like, and now they are nicknamed Sanno-san.
During the amalgamation of Buddhism with the indigenous religion Shinto, the shrines were named Sanno, Sannno-Gongen, Hiyoshi-Sanno, and the like, and now they are nicknamed Sanno-san.
During the amalgamation of Buddhism with the indigenous religion Shinto, the shrines were named Sanno, Sannno-Gongen, Hiyoshi-Sanno, and the like, and now they are nicknamed Sanno-san.

sen.j: 日吉神社の神使は猿であるが、猿との関連性についてはよく分かっていない。
sen.e: Monkey is considered the sacred messenger of Hiyoshijinja Shrine, but the relationship between the shrine and monkey is unknown.
Monkey is considered the sacred messenger of Hiyoshijinja Shrine, but the relationship between the shrine and monkey is unknown.
Monkey is considered the sacred messenger of Hiyoshijinja Shrine, but the relationship between the shrine and monkey is unknown.

sen.j: おそらくは原始信仰の名残りではないかと推測されている。
sen.e: It is supposed that 'the monkey' has been inherited from a primitive belief.
This is presumed to be a legacy of a primitive belief.
This is presumed to be a legacy of a primitive belief.

sen.j: 大社自体も大宮(大比叡・本地釈梼如来)、二宮(小比叡・本地薬師如来)を山王両明神とし、聖真子(本地阿弥陀如来)を加えて山王三所または三聖といい、やがて八王子(本地千手観音)、客人(本地十一面観音)、十禅師(本地地蔵菩醍)、三宮(本地普賢菩醍)を加えて山王七社（上七社）となすなど、総本山の威容を整え始めた。
sen.e: Hiyoshitaisha Shrine began to have its dignified appearance as the head shrine by having Daigu (or Daihiei, enshrining Honjishakujunyorai) and Ninomiya (or Kohiei, enshrining Honjiyakushinyorai) as gracious deities at both sides, by adding Shoshinshi (enshrining Honjiamidanyorai) later to collectively call three of them Sanno Sanjo or Sansei, and by further adding Hachioji (enshrining Honjisenjukannon), Kyakujin (enshrining Honjijuichimenkannon), Juzenji (enshrining Honjijizobodai), and Sangu (enshrining Honjifugenbodai) to collectively call them Sanno nanasha (Kami nanasha).

Hiyoshitaisha Shrine began to have its dignified appearance as the head shrine by having Daigu (or Daihiei, original enshrined deity: Shakuju Nyorai) and Ninomiya (or Kohiei, original enshrined deity: Yakushi Nyorai) as gracious deities at both sides, by adding Shoshinshi (original enshrined deity: Amida Nyorai) later to collectively call three of them Sanno Sanjo or Sansei, and by further adding Hachioji (original enshrined deity: Senju Kannon), Kyakujin (original enshrined deity: Juichimen Kannon), Juzenji (original enshrined deity: Jizo Bodai), and Sangu (original enshrined deity: Fugen Bodai) to collectively call them Sanno nanasha (Kami nanasha).

Hiyoshitaisha Shrine began to have its dignified appearance as the head shrine by having Daigu (or Daihiei, original enshrined deity: Shakuju Nyorai) and Ninomiya (or Kohiei, original enshrined deity: Yakushi Nyorai) as gracious deities at both sides, by adding Shoshinshi (original enshrined deity: Amida Nyorai) later to collectively call three of them Sanno Sanjo or Sansei, and by further adding Hachioji (original enshrined deity: Senju Kannon), Kyakujin (original enshrined deity: Juichimen Kannon), Juzenji (original enshrined deity: Jizo Bodai), and Sangu (original enshrined deity: Fugen Bodai) to collectively call them Sanno nanasha (Kami nanasha).

sen.j: そして本地垂迹説によってさらに数を増し中七社、下七社を加えて「山王二十一社」と称した。
sen.e: According to the theory of Honji Suijakusetsu, it increased its subshrines by seven as nakananasha and seven as shimonanasha to call the whole of the shrines 'Sanno 21 shrines'.
According to the theory of Honji Suijakusetsu, it increased its subshrines by seven as nakananasha and seven as shimonanasha to call the whole of the shrines 'Sanno 21 shrines'.
According to the theory of Honji Suijakusetsu, it increased its subshrines by seven as nakananasha and seven as shimonanasha to call the whole of the shrines 'Sanno 21 shrines'.

sen.j: 中世に比叡山の僧兵が強訴のために担ぎ出した神輿は日吉大社のものである。
sen.e: The portable shrines carried by warrior monks of Mt. Hiei for a direct petition in the mediaeval era belonged to Hiyoshitaisha Shrine.
The portable shrines carried by warrior monks of Mt. Hiei for a direct petition in the mediaeval era belonged to Hiyoshitaisha Shrine.
The portable shrines carried by warrior monks of Mt. Hiei for a direct petition in the mediaeval era belonged to Hiyoshitaisha Shrine.

sen.j: 元亀2年（1571年）、織田信長の比叡山焼き討ち (1571年)により、日吉大社も灰燼に帰した。
sen.e: Hiyoshitaisha Shrine was burned down in the Siege of Mt. Hiei headed by Nobunaga ODA.
In 1571, Hiyoshitaisha Shrine was burned down in the Siege of Mt. Hiei headed by Nobunaga ODA.
In 1571, Hiyoshitaisha Shrine was burned down in the Siege of Mt. Hiei headed by Nobunaga ODA.

sen.j: 現在見られる建造物は、安土桃山時代以降に再建されたものである。
sen.e: The shrine buildings were reconstructed after the Azuchi-Momoyama period.
The shrine buildings that still exist today were reconstructed after the Azuchi-Momoyama period.
sen.cmt: 「現在見られる」の訳抜けを訂正しました。
sen.e: The shrine buildings that still exist today were reconstructed after the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

sen.j: 以下に現在の日吉神社の有力社殿（山王二十一社）を列記する。
sen.e: The current biggest shrines called Sanno 21 shrines are listed below.
The existent main buildings of Hiyoshitaisha Shrine called Sanno 21 shrines are listed below.
sen.cmt: 「有力社殿」の訳語を修正しました。
sen.e: The existent main buildings of Hiyoshitaisha Shrine called Sanno 21 shrines are listed below.

sen.j: 気比社（気比）仲哀天皇
sen.e: Kehisha (Kehi) Chuaitenno
Kehisha (Kehi) Chuaitenno
Kehisha (Kehi) Chuaitenno

sen.j: なお江戸で「三大祭」として賑わったのは、山王祭（さんのうまつり）、神田祭、深川祭であるが、この山王まつりとは、徳川家康が江戸に移封された際に、同地にあった日吉社を城内の紅葉山に遷座し、江戸城の鎮守としたことに始まる。
sen.e: Among Sannomatsuri, Kandamatsuri, and Fukagawamatsuri that were crowded with people during the Edo period as 'Three Major Festivals', Sannomatsuri began when Ieyasu TOKUGAWA was transferred to a new fief Edo and Ieyasu transferred Hiyoshisha Shrine to the Momijiyama hill within Edo-jo Castle to make it the guardian deity of the castle.

Sannomatsuri was one of Three Major Festivals in Edo together with Kandamatsuri and Fukagawamatsuri that were crowded with people, and it began when Ieyasu TOKUGAWA was transferred to a new domain of Edo and Ieyasu transferred Hiyoshisha Shrine to the Momijiyama hill within Edo-jo Castle to make it the guardian deity of the castle.
sen.cmt: 訳の修正、fiefをdomain ofに修正しました。
sen.e: Sannomatsuri was one of Three Major Festivals in Edo together with Kandamatsuri and Fukagawamatsuri that were crowded with people, and it began when Ieyasu TOKUGAWA was transferred to a new domain of Edo and Ieyasu transferred Hiyoshisha Shrine to the Momijiyama hill within Edo-jo Castle to make it the guardian deity of the castle.

sen.j: この社の由来は、太田道灌が江戸城築城にあたり、文明 (日本)10年（1478年）に川越の無量寿寺（現在の喜多院）の鎮守である日吉社を勧請したのにはじまるとされる。
sen.e: This Hiyoshisha Shrine was originally branched from the Hiyoshisha Shrine that was the guardian deity of Muryojuji Temple (present Kitain Temple) in Kawagoe in 1478 by Dokan OTA when he constructed Edo-jo Castle.

This Hiyoshisha Shrine was originally branched from the Hiyoshisha Shrine that was the guardian deity of Muryojuji Temple (present Kitain Temple) in Kawagoe in 1478 by Dokan OTA when he constructed Edo-jo Castle.

This Hiyoshisha Shrine was originally branched from the Hiyoshisha Shrine that was the guardian deity of Muryojuji Temple (present Kitain Temple) in Kawagoe in 1478 by Dokan OTA when he constructed Edo-jo Castle.

sen.j: 無量寿寺は平安初期の天長7年（830年）、淳和天皇の命で円仁（慈覚大師）が建立したとされる。
sen.e: It is said that Muryojuji Temple was built by Ennin (also known as Jikakudaishi) on orders of Emperor Junna in 830 during the early Heian period.
It is said that Muryojuji Temple was built by Ennin (also known as Jikakudaishi) on orders of Emperor Junna in 830 during the early Heian period.
It is said that Muryojuji Temple was built by Ennin (also known as Jikakudaishi) on orders of Emperor Junna in 830 during the early Heian period.

sen.j: ちなみに、この江戸の日吉社に日枝（ひえ）神社と名称が付けられたのは、慶応4年（明治元年）6月11日以降のことである。
sen.e: Incidentally, the Hiyoshisha Shrine in Edo was renamed Hiejinja Shrine after July 30, 1868.
Incidentally, the Hiyoshisha Shrine in Edo was renamed Hiejinja Shrine after July 30, 1868.
Incidentally, the Hiyoshisha Shrine in Edo was renamed Hiejinja Shrine after July 30, 1868.

sen.j: （神仏分離）
sen.e: (due to Shinbutsubunri edit to separate shinto and Buddhism)
(due to Shinbutsubunri edict to separate Shinto and Buddhism)
(due to Shinbutsubunri edict to separate Shinto and Buddhism)

sen.j: 天台宗が全国に広がる過程で、山王権現も各地に勧請され、多くは天台宗の寺院の鎮守神とされた。
sen.e: As the Tendai sect was propagated across Japan, Sanno Gongen was branched and constructed across Japan mostly to be the guardian deity of the Tendai sect temples.
As the Tendai sect was propagated across Japan, Sanno Gongen was branched and constructed across Japan mostly to be the guardian deity of the Tendai sect temples.
As the Tendai sect was propagated across Japan, Sanno Gongen was branched and constructed across Japan mostly to be the guardian deity of the Tendai sect temples.

sen.j: 明治の神仏分離の際に、仏教色を廃し寺院とは別れた。
sen.e: Under the edict of Shinbutsubunri promulgated by the Meiji government, the influence of Buddhism on Sanno Gongen was removed and Sanno Gongen were separated from the temples.
Under the edict of Shinbutsubunri promulgated by the Meiji government, the influence of Buddhism on Sanno Gongen was removed and Sanno Gongen were separated from the temples.
Under the edict of Shinbutsubunri promulgated by the Meiji government, the influence of Buddhism on Sanno Gongen was removed and Sanno Gongen were separated from the temples.

sen.j: 社名については、「日吉」と書いて「ひえ」と読むもの、「日吉」と書いて「ひよし」と読むもの、「日枝」と書いて「ひえ」と読むものがある。
sen.e: The shrine names '日吉' is pronounced as 'Hiei' for some temples, '日吉' is pronounced as 'Hiyoshi' for some temples, and '日枝' is pronounced as 'Hiei' for some temples.
The shrine names '日吉' is pronounced as 'Hie' for some temples, '日吉' is pronounced as 'Hiyoshi' for some temples, and '日枝' is pronounced as 'Hie' for some temples.
The shrine names '日吉' is pronounced as 'Hie' for some temples, '日吉' is pronounced as 'Hiyoshi' for some temples, and '日枝' is pronounced as 'Hie' for some temples.
